notes: Rosalie Nichols says feminist bookstores should cooperate and exchange information and mentions that lesbian and feminist writers are neglected by mass market publishers, also encourages the newsletter writers not to self-sacrifice their labor by not allowing ads and taking on printing costs themselves. Alternative Booksellers mentions high rent prices and an entirely volunteer staff.

author: Carol Seajay
notes: graphic: feminist bookstore news logo. text: FBN income since Sept. 1976 was $973, and expenses were $1,164, so a new subscription year begins in December. Not enough subscriptions have come in since last April. Andre is no longer working on the newsletter. CS wants to do the newsletter every 6 weeks because the timing of every month is hard on her. She enjoys doing FBN, but would be willing to pass it on. Should individuals be allowed to purchase FBN copies?

author: Carol Seajay
notes: Seajay's response to Elizabeth Lay's letter.

author: Diana [Diana Press]
notes: Diana's Press, 4400 Market Street, Oakland CA 94608. was broken into October 25, 1977. Thousands of books are destroyed by chemical substances such as solvents. TYpesettings, pasted-up books, negatives, and plates were destroyed as well. Suspects are believed to be women. They suspect governmental agents, women in the movement opposed to Diana's Press and FEN, or a combination of both. Feminists who are anti-capitalists are mentioned as a motive. Made possible by the climate of verbal violence. Finances are in trouble because of the vandalism, and emotional stability and morale have struggled. "We need women to send us donations".

author: Eleanor [Womanbooks]
notes: Bookstore list: Woman's Eye in St. Louis and Birmingham in Pittsburgh. Womanbooks has Battered Wives and Of Woman Born in paper now. Shares feelings about KNOW (doesn't like them very much). Ask visitors to bring something to put in a scrapbook.

author: Elizabeth Lay
notes: Lay & Singer - Feminist Literacy Agency. Established in July of 1977. Feminist business with the goal of publishing and media of women writers. Funded out of their own pockets. Asks to subscribe to FBN for $8.

author: Elizabeth Lay
notes: Shelly Singer and Elizabeth Lay started their business this summer with no publishing experience. Describes how the business came to be through struggles and triumphs. FBN helps a lot. Lay visited Diana's Press after the break-in to access some of the damages. Discusses her experience with that.

author: Isabel Santos
notes: Santos found FBN through Vancouver Women's Bookstores. Santos is a part of a non-profit publishing house publishing feminist media in Portugal, Lisbon. Open to supporting with translation. Avenida Sidonio Pais, 28, 5.DTO, Lisboa Portugal.

author: Jean [Womanspirit]
notes: FBN costs $2 per issue, Jean finds that fascinating. Starting production of the winter issue. Jean asks how to collect an over-due account, and then lists who owes her. Carol Seajay response on same page with no title or spacing from Jean's letter.

author: Carol Seajay
notes:
No money to publish the issue until Anyda Marchant's and Muriel Crawford's gift. Encourage people to subscribe. Request for someone to write a murder mysteries column. Seajay attending Second International Feminist Bookfair in Oslo, wants to make non-American books more available to US feminist bookstores. The Color Purple is popular with 3 million copies in print, but we have a ways to go, since romance writers often have 60 million copies in print. So don't declare success or fold up shop despite being understaffed and underpaid.

article_title: Flack from Canadian Customs Retroactive Censorship?!?
author: James McPhee [Glad Day Bookshop]
notes:
The Joy of Gay Sex sold in Canada since 1977, now in 1986 after a complaint to police it's facing retroactive censorship and has suddenly been placed on customs' list of banned books and magazines. The list has never been available to the public. McPhee says pay no attention to the list and that it's arbitrary and has no legal standing.
Graphics:
p. 12 protesters

article_title: Gay and Lesbian Books Fight Customs to Enter New Zealand
author: Jenny Rankine
notes:
Imported lesbian and gay books seized by customs and judged indecent by Indecent Publications Tribunal. One example of a book that is not sexually explicit, but deemed indecent for people under 18 because it "could give offense." Others indecent because they "glamorize homosexuality." Staff of London's Gay's The Word bookshop facing two years imprisonment, literary observers see this trial as landmark test case for literary censorship
Graphics:
p. 10 bed encircled by "Keep bigotry outta my bedroom."; p. 11  open book with silhouette of protesters with text "Defend Gay's The Word Campaign, London's Gay Community Bookshop"

author: Unknown
notes:
Randall had deportation hearing, INS argued she was excludable as a communist, some reasons were her political cartoons and poetry, editing poetry journals, exchanging the journal with US underground newspapers, interviewing communists for her books, admitting to being a Marxist, and being an atheist. She's appealing the deportation, readers are encouraged to discuss the case, send contributions to her defense committee, sell and display her work, and write protest letters to the INS and local congresspeople.

article_title: The Second Annual Feminist Bookfair - Oslo
author: Carol Seajay
notes:
-Booksellers attended in small numbers, little trans-Atlantic dealing in rights sales. Strongest aspect of fair was its identity as a Women's writing festival. . . "we were a walking literature of the international women in print movement" (10). Conference promoted lesbian visibility despite high percentage of lesbian participants. Regret that Global Day and Lesbian Celebration were scheduled to conflict with each other, so people had to decide if they were global or lesbian. Goals of feminist bookfairs should be clearly stated from the start. "More than anything, an international bookfair needs to provide a cross-fertilization of ideas" (13).
Graphics: 
p. 10 CWS: Post Nairobi, credit: International Women's Tribune Centre, graphic of globe with text "As a woman I have no country. . . my country is the whole world," text below "From the globe outside the peace tent. . . Nairobi, Kenya 1985"
p. 11 2nd International Feminist Book Fair Oslo logo - side profile of woman overlaid with disintegrating quill pen and feminism symbol/venus symbol
p. 12 CWS: Post Nairobi, credit: Third World Women's News, graphic of fist crushing feminism symbol/venus symbol, with outline of South America in the symbol's circle
p. 13 CWS: Post Nairobi graphic of woman with sash raising fist, sash has foreign language text
p. 13 somewhat abstract graphic of woman, buildings, bird, sun, Spanish text below says "amnistía internacional: libertad para los presos de conciencia, juicios imparciales para todos los presos políticos, abolición de la tortura y la pena de muerte, en todo el mundo"
my translation: “amnesty international: freedom for all prisoners of conscience, fair trials for all political prisoners, abolition of torture and the death penalty, around the world”

author: Carol Seajay
notes:
-All charges dropped against Gay's The Word bookstore and its directors. Customs returned all books. Customs surrender result of protest by lesbian and gay community. “Hindsight guesses, trying to explain the ferocity of the raids, are that Customs came to the bookstore genuinely expecting (hoping?) to find a full-fledged gay pornography outfit importing all their wildest fantasies and that the officers were convinced that somewhere, if they just look under and behind everything, (and in everyone’s bedroom) they would find what they imagined was there. And they didn’t know what to do when they encountered literature. And didn’t know how to back down” (14). Instead of Customs having secret lists of banned topics, now they state in advance whether or not a book contravenes import prohibitions, and the importer can challenge Customs in open court without risking loss of stock/criminal charges.
Graphics:
p. 14 customs document

Their first two books will be Child of Her People by Anne Cameron and Living By The Light by Shakti Gawain; The Women Against Racism Committee at the University of Iowa have organized a national conference called Parallels & Intersections focusing on Racism and other forms of oppression; The Meridel Le Sueur Library Foundation is raising money to build a structure to house the library that Meridel has collected; The National Women's History Project has a new poster for Black Bistory Monthand a catalog of suggestions for Women's History Month; Naiad's ABA authors for 1989 will be Claire McNab to sign Death Down Under and Sarah Aldrich signing Keep To Me Stranger. article_title: Back To Press And Other Good News
author: Unknown
notes: Movie Rights: Spinsters/Aunt Lute had 8 bids for the TV movie rights to Why Can't Sharon Kowalski Come Home?. Richard Schmiechen and David Haugland were chosen as the producers for the TV Movie.; Awards: Politics of the Heart edited by Sandra Pollack and Jeanne Vaughn received the 1988 Susan Koppelman Award for Popular Culture given by the Women's Caucus of Popular Culture/American Culture Association. A Restricted Country by Joan Nestle and And the Band Played On by Randy Shilts were the co-recipients of the American Library Associations Gay Book Award. When I am an Old Woman  I shall Wear Purple published by Papier Mache Press received Publishers' Marketing Association's Franklin Award for literature. "Johnnieruth" by Becky Birtha in Lovers' Choice was published in Pushcart XIII; Rights: Cleis Press acquired th Unites States rights to Don't: a Woman's Word by Elly Danica. Rights for The Monarchs are Flying have been sold to The Women's Press in Canada, Pandora Press in Engand, and Argument in Germany. Naiad Press sold the German rights to Murder at the Nightwood Bar and Amateur City to Argument. The Always Anonymous Beast was purchased by them last year. Daphne Verlog purchased Lessons in Murder. They previously purchased curious Wine, Outlander, and The House at Pelham Falls; Back to Press: Internal Affairs: A Journalkeeping Workbook for Self-Intimacy by Kay Hagan sold out its first 1,000 copies and went back for 5,000 second prining. The Little School: Tales of Disappearance and Survival in Argentina went for a third printing. Sex Work: Writings by Women in the Sex Industry went for a second printing. Lesbian Couples by Merilee Clunis has 14,000 copies in print. Homegirls and Handgrenades by Sonia Sanchez has gone back for a seventh printing. The Crossing Press Announced that Colors and Crystals by Joy Gardner, The Inner Dance and Mother Wit by Diane Mariechild will all be reprinted. Long Time Passing: Lives of Older Lesbians edited by Marcy Adelman will have a second printing. Hard Times Cotton Mill Girls: Personal Histories of Womanhood and Poverty in the South by Victoria Byerly will be printed again, The Dance of Anger by Harriet Lerner will be reprinted for the 15th time. The Courage to Heal by Ellen Bass and Laura Davis will be reprinted for the fifth time. The Assertive Woman: A New Look by Stanlee Phelps and Nancy Austin has been reprinted for the third time.

author: Unknown
notes: 1989 Crossroad/Continuum Women's Studies Award: Crossroad/Continuum offering $5,000 advance and publication in the Fall of 1989 for completed manuscripts about Women's studies; African American Life Series: Wayne State University announced the new publication of the African American Life Series. Edited by Toni Cade Bambara, Geneva Smitherman-Donaldson, Wilbur Rich, and Ronald W. Walters; Differences: Indiana University Press has released a new journal of cultural studies called Differences. It is published three times a year and edited by Naomi Schor and Elizabeth Weed of the Pembroke Center for Teaching and Research on Women at Brown University.

author: Carol Seajay
notes: Starts by addressing the  compliments on the new look of FBN due to their use of computer, laser printer, and software. Mentions that Donna Murray will continue to work on the Canadian Content column, and calls for anyone interested in working on a Canadian book column. This issue contains the article "Why Support Feminist Presses" by Shane Snowden as a separate sheet, and it is encouraged that it be copied and shared. Seajay also introduces the next issue's topic of recovery and asks if anyone is interested in writing an article on recovery and working in a feminist bookstore, as well as blurbs for "recovery fiction" and other topics.

article_title: Special Requests at the Terminist Bookstore

article_title: A Closing Letter from the Organizers

author: Libby Oughton

There is a short recap of their year. Finally, the author thanks everyone who has helped after the fire. Graphics: Drawing of two maple tree leaves with music notes in them.

author: Marian Lens

article_title: The First Annual Lambda Literary Awards
author: Unknown
notes: Introduces the Lambda Literary Awards, an award started by Book Report to recognize gay and lesbian writing and publishing. Invites nominations from readers and book sellers Explains the nomination and judging process, as well as the guidelines. Announces a gala for the winners. Finally, a nomination form is included. Graphic: Lambda Rising Book Report logo.

author: An Anonymous Bookstore Worker; Recovering Co-Addict; Alcoholic
notes:
The author describes her relationship to Al-Anon after having been with an alcoholic partner, and how she started a feminist bookstore with other women in several types of recovery, began developing a collection of books related to addiction and recovery, and the issues that arise in their unique workforce. Titles mentioned include Good Enough to Eat by Leslea Newman and Leave a Light On for Me by Jean Swallow. 
Same illustration as article above of a hand holding grain in front of the sun.

author: Carol Seajay
notes:
Begins by describing violence in reaction to Ayatollah Khomeini's death threats against Salman Rushdie for his book The Satanic Verses, including Cody's Books and Waldenbooks on Telegraph Avenue being firebombed. Other subjects covered in the introduction include attempts by the Women-in-Print conference to be more inclusive of Women of Color, welcoming new columnists Nett Hart and Mary Lowry, and a job ad for Office Manager / Production Coordinator at FBN.
Then introduces the theme of the issue with the headline "Recovery is a Feminist Issue"; argues that community movements toward sobriety should be better highlighted in feminist social movements.

article_title: Is This a Business or a Political Organization?: Some opening dialogue on the way to Women-in-Print #4
author: Nett Hart
notes:
Under the heading "But Can She Type?"
Describes the diversification of the Women’s Liberation Movement (WLM) and how some see it as divisive, but the author sees it as a strength. Notes the mainstreaming of feminist literature, and urges the Women-in-Print movement to discuss thoughtfully among themselves how they want to approach this phenomenon, focusing on political action and not on entrepreneurship.
Includes an illustration credited to Sudie Rakusin (from Wickedary), an image of three Women's faces, and an image of a bookshelf.

article_title: Censorship and Silence: But Can She Type?
author: Nett Hart
notes: "If nothing else, feminism is about hearing one another into speech, reading one another in print. Still, we are best at hearing what is familiar, finding merit in what is correlative. Because ownership of bookstore and publishing resources is not as diverse as our movement is, the silences are still with us. There are gaps on the shelves of realities that have not yet been heard into speech/print." (23)

article_title: Moving it Along Thoughts on Being Part of the Travels of Sinister Wisdom
author: Elana Dykewomon
notes:
Graphic: p. 17 is a crop from the image on the front cover of the issue; profile of a woman with hair in ponytail and a large bird with open wings is merged with part of her face
- piece by Elana Dykewomon about Sinister Wisdom journal in its 14th year; she was the 7th editor and publisher; writes of it's movement creating a new home that is constantly added upon; this motion makes it unique; there is no one point of view at SW all the dykes have different personal philosophies, styles, audiences, etc. which has enabled it to continue being published; the journal is an act of revolutionary love and trust as well as conversation with lesbians both past, present, and future; piece stresses the collective production of the journal, revolutionary hope, time, place, and travel

article_title: And Now ... A Word From Your Local Librarian
author: Susan Searing [Women's Studies Librarian University Of Wisconsin System]
notes:
Graphic: p. 13 a stick figure comic of a women and bookstacks
- notes tension between librarians and booksellers and compares libraries and bookstores noting that bookstores are better for browing because they tend to display materials in more inviting ways and the libraries are bound to a classification system that is antiquated and predates modern feminism; demonstrates unique role of Women's bookstore in being the only local source for lesbian romances, radical political pamphlets, and alternative periodicals

author: Unknown
notes: 4 short news blurbs. "Illinois Prison Relents on Banned Book": Illinois Department of Corrections had rescinded its ban of an interracial gay novel from state prisons, Larry Duplechan's "Eight Days A Week".; "Canadian Francophone Lesbian Bookseller Wins ABA Scholarship": L'Androgyne staffer, France Desilets, had been awarded a Minority Scholarship to the ABA's Booksellers School.;  "James Tiptree, JR Memorial Award": Pat Murphy announced the James Tiptree Jr. Memorial Award, which "will be presented annually to a fictional work that explores and expands the roles of women and men." James Tiptree Jr. was really Alice Sheldon & the new award has the support of Sheldon's estate. Funds to finance the award will be raised through bake sales at sci-fi conventions around the country. There will also be sales of the published recipes being solicited.;  "Readers Guide Still Refuses to index Gay/Lesbian Periodicals": Major periodical indices have resisted listing gay and lesbian publications, but the Gay and Lesbian Task Force of the American Library Association has convinced two of the leading indexing companies to start listing lesbian and gay magazines. Infotrac and The Book Review Index agreed to list select magazines. The Readers Guide to Periodical Literature, the major periodical guide, has refused to stop snubbing gay magazines. The gay and lesbian library workers are asking for a call to action from their library patrons, to write to Readers Guide and ask to stop their "biased omission".

author: Ann Christopherson [Women & Children First; Chicago]

Recommends buying from Indiana, Harvard, California, Columbia, Illinois, Chicago Nebraska, Minnesota, Michigan, and Cornell. Regional bias for bookselling. Recommends getting a rep to order books. Ordering selectively minimizes returns. Graphics: Paragraph breaks with square illustrations of a spiral-bound book.

author: Ann Morse
notes: Gay and Lesbian art space Rhino Nest opened. Bookmobile service started called Travellin' Pages, they go to gay bars. Mystery Love Company, a bookstore, opened. Someone wanted to open a feminist bookstore in CA, four bookshops added more feminist/lesbian works to their stores. Emma Women's Books closing, Alternatives Corner closed. Announcement of new staff in multiple stores. Graphic: Logo for Rhino Nest

author: Carol Seajay

article_title: Publishing Triangle Contemplates National Lesbian/Gay Book Month
author: Carol Seajay
notes: Article about how The Publishing Triangle, and new york networking group for gay and lesbian people in the publishing industry is planning to have a nationwide lesbian/gay book month, scheduled for June 1992. It would encourage publishers to have special promotions/launches. Bookstores could have special displays, and media could cover it. Some ideas to contribute to it include a package for bookstores with promotion materials and making a list of gay media contacts. There is a concern about mainstream stores that join in getting more media coverage than stores that specialize in gay/lesbian books. They are planning for June because it is also Pride Month. They encourage comments to Roz Parr at A Different Light. Graphic: small illustration of a protest

author: Carol Seajay
notes: Flat sales in December for most feminist bookstores. Ottawa Women's Bookstore had very good sales. Canada's General Sales Tax did not hurt sales for OWB. Graphic:  illustration of woman carrying books in the snow

author: Carol Seajay
notes: Sue Butterworth and Jane Cholmeley bookstore Silver Moon expanded into The Old Collet's Bookshop. Rent will increase by 200%  Graphic: illustration of a pile of books

author: Carol Seajay
notes: Anne Harbaugh owner of Mother Kali's Bookstore given Harvey Milk Award. Mother Kali's is only Women's bookstore in northwest. Theresa Corrigan owner of Lioness Bookstore given River City Democratic Club's Community Service Award

author: Carol Seajay
notes: Red and Black, a leftist, progressive, feminist, gay/lesbian bookstore, went up on Wordstock. Sponsored a Dead Writer's Evening.

author: Carol Seajay
notes: New Words "Frequent Reader Plan" is a big success. Lioness Bookstore had a Women's craftsfair that was expensive and didn't work in 1991, they held an open house in 1992 that did work and brought in business

author: Carol Seajay
notes: Graphic: courtesy of a Room of One's own, signs with phrases "I'd rather be reading," "Thelma & Louise Live," "I think therefore I read," "I believe Anita Hill," and "so many books so little time." A Room of One's Own in Madison was victim of a trash fire, the fire only destroyed a window. Firefighters used chemicals to put out the fire instead of water, so the books had to be cleaned.

author: Carol Seajay
notes: Alaska Women's Bookstore faced a the Exhibiting Obscene Materials law that would have made it unlawful to sell obscene materials. The law would have included everything in the store's lesbian, sexuality, and video sections. Right-wing christians and survivors of abuse sponsored the law. Third hearing permanently stopped the law. Graphic: political comic about Madison Avenue Discovering lesbians

author: Carol Seajay
notes: Ottawa Women's Bookstore could only find seven titles from university presses when asked for a bestseller list

article_title: Happy Valentines Day Happy Birthday, Inland
author: Carol Seajay
notes: Inland sold its first books on Valentine's Day. Interview with David Wilk. 50 people working at Inland. Inland did not have a computer the first two years. Gay and feminist bookstores Inland's primary customers. Inland lists their goals, to give an avenue for publishers to distribute, and to make a living. Inland is known as a good place to work for gay people, alternative folks, and "weird" people. Inland has an "excellent fulfillment" rate.  Graphics: various comics. First one is someone asking where David is, the second one is someone expressing disbelief that David is listening to all the cassette tapes. The third one is David with two boxes in front of him saying "yes" and "no",

article_title: Teacher College Press buys Athene Series

article_title: The Cutting Edge: Lesbian Life & Literature
author: Carol Seajay
notes: New York University had a lesbian series and their first titles were out in July 1992. Series edited by Karla Jay. Says there's growing attention to lesbian writings but lesbian classics aren't in print. Two aims: representative examples of lesbian literature by reissuing classics. Multiple never-published novels including Ladies Almanack, I Know My Own Heart, and In (Sem)Erotics: Theorizing Lesbian Writing. Graphics: Covers of the books

author: Carol Seajay

author: Carol Seajay

Michigan Womyn's Music Festival people reduced number of booths for publishers. Newsweek did an issue on lesbian magazine Deneuve calling lesbians "man-haters in clogs." New Pages collecting info for a directory of bookstores. Graphics: bubble-letter punctuation symbols, illustration of two cat bookends

author: Carol Seajay
notes: ABA Board of directors announces Minority Bookseller Education Grant. Lesbian Writers fund accepting entries for 1992 grants. NWSA is holding a conference about Feminist Education. Women in Russia wrote to FBN regarding a newsletter on Women's movements in Russia. Graphics: illustrations of bulletin boards

author: Carol Seajay
notes: Graphic: illustration of two people typing on typewriters by Liz Prager, illustration of woman laughing with a book and doing dishes by Denise Kierans, logo for National Women's History Project, Illustration of two people on a magic carpet coming out of a book flying towards a city. List of feminist publishers who have written short book announcements. Aunt Lute Books recommends Send my Roots Rain. Naiad Press announces A Flight of Angels, Attic Press announces Against the Grain: The Contemporary Women's Movement in Northern Ireland. Children's Book Press announces I Remember 121, Cleis Press Recommends Boomer: Railroad Memoirs. National Women's History Project announces Las Mujeres: Mexican/Chicana Women. Post-Apollo Press announces Josef is Dying. Southern Sisters announce Pornography & Civil Rights. Wages Due Lesbians announces Policing the Bedroom and How We Can Refuse.

article_title: Favorite University Press Titles of the Moment
author: Carol Seajay; Mary Morell [Full Circle Books]; K. Murphy [Mama Bears]; Kris Hoover [Amazon Bookstore]; Sandi Torkildson [A Room Of One's Own]; Mary Lowry [New Words]; Izzy Harbaugh [Mother Kali's]; Tom Brandeberry [Valley Women's Bookstore]; Rose Katz [Black Oak Books]
notes: Informal poll of feminist booksellers about their favorite university press title. Mary Morell recommends From Surviving to Thriving: Incest, Feminism, and Recovery. K. Murphy recommends When the Moon Waxes Red,  Women, Native, Other: Writing Postcoloniality & Feminism. Kris Hoover recommends Both Right and Left Handed: Arab Women Talk About Their Lives. Sandi Torkildson recommends Period Piece, Odd Girls and Twilight Lovers, and Alchemy of Race and Rights. Mary Lowry recommends Everyone Here Spoke Sign Language: Hereditary Deafness on Martha's Vineyard. Izzy Harbaugh recommends In Stitches: A Patchwork of Feminist Humor and Satire. Tom Brandenberry recommends Rape of the Wild. Rose Katz recommends Showing Our Colors: Afro-German Women Speak Out. Graphic: illustration of two women writing by Rini Templeton

article_title: Saying 'No' to Sexual Harassment Equals Obscenity
author: Lesbian Information Service
notes: Lesbian editors of Greek magazine AMPHI taken to jail for publishing "indecent" material. Calls for letters of protest

author: Renee Albrecht [Women's Bookshop]; Lea Fletcher [Feminaria]; Chai Mckee [Woman Of Power]; Midge Stocker [Rising Tide Press; Womankind Books]; Lee Boojamra [Womankind Books; Rising Tide Press]; Deke Nihilson [Three Dollar Bill]
notes: Little illustrations of letters throughout the pages. Renee Albrecht volunteered to write the Canadian content articles, positive review of Looking For Livingstone Lea Fletcher asked for solidarity from FBN after Dr. Temma Kaplan and her staff at the Bernard Center for Research were made to resign. Midge Stocker's thoughts on publishing lesbian/feminist plays, there is not a large market for them, recommends publishing them similarly to Chicago Plays Inc, one play in a saddle-bound volume and covers with only one color, the play would also have to be put on at least once. Lee Boojamra encourage Susanna to make a list of sci-fi/fantasy books with lesbian plots. Sci-fi/fantasy manuscripts they receive are usually not high-quality. Boojamra wants Susanna to add Rising Tide to a list of publishers willing to publish sci-fi/fantasy, readers are asking for that Genre,  not interested in publishing anything without a Lesbian protagonist or plot. Deke Nihilson thank you note for mentioning Three Dollar Bill in FBN's coverage, FBN's advertising prices are out of Three Dollar Bill's price range

Bestsellers include After the Ball, Buddies, Invisible Lives, Social Construction of Lesbianism, Odd Girls and Twilight Lovers, Arena of Masculinity, Lesbian Love Advisor, Lesbian Love Stories. article_title: Gay Sex Finally in Print, but Hassles Continue
author: Unknown
notes: Book from Alyson Press Gay Sex was turned down by 18 printers but is in stores. The book shows male sexual activity, but is not pornographic, and was turned down because it was considered pornographic. Printers are located in small towns, where they get a tax break in exchange for having an amount of jobs available to the town, part of that deal was not including pornographic material. Because of the media publicity, the print run for Gay Sex increased by 60%

article_title: ABA Board "Defeats" (?!) Resolution to Protect Independent Bookselling
author: Carol Seajay
notes: ABA board "defeated" a resolution from an independent bookseller asking them to establish a five-point program to protect independent bookselling. Two chains threatened ABA with a lawsuit if the proposal passed. The resolution asked for the following: Commitment of ABA to preserving independent bookstore, ABA stadd researching issues related to preserving independent bookstores, ABA public campaign about the issue, ABA support to law enforcement efforts to end discriminatory pricing, ABA persuading congress to investigate issues w/independent bookstores.

Croft [Our Power Press]; Carol Seajay; Sasha Alyson [Alyson Publications]; Bernard E. Rath [American Booksellers Association]
notes: Colleen Ernst says her bookstore has had an excellent year and added another full-time staff person, Jeri Burns. Jahnet Hewsick says Canada's customs seized 35 copies of Hothead Paisan. Marge writes that Wild Seeds Bookstore & Cafe has closed. Renee Albrecht says that business is good and feminists in Hamilton have turned against each other, the bookstore held a crafts night to help bridge that gap. Cathy writes about an article in a previous issue listing interview questions for hiring, and says the question "Do you have personal responsibilities which may inhibit your duties" is not worded correctly. Jennifer S. Croft writes about a protest on November fourth by gays and lesbians, expresses anger about Colorado being able to vote on their rights. Carol Seajay has a letter that appeared in Publisher's weekly about the boycott of Amendment 2 in Colorado, which repeals the rights of three communities, 11 additional states have considered the same, encourages people to Boycott Colorado. Sasha Alyson writes a letter to the ABA about increased convention fees. Bernard E. Rath responds to Sasha Alyson, saying they've heard about these concerns before, explains that entry-level booths have been phased out as a result of show growth and demand.

article_title: Women In Print Contingent at March on Washington Be there!
author: Fbn
notes: Feminist Bookstores and Publishers will have events in the March on Washington in April. There was a dinner for feminist bookstores, FBN is doing PR, registration, and acting as a treasurer. The theme for the events is "Healthy Feminist bookstores and Publishers: What do they look like?" Looking to make 50-100 signs for the March. They're also looking for photographers.

article_title: Canada Customs Hits Feminist Stores and Others
author: Fbn
notes: Canada Customs seized magazines from two general bookstores. thirty-five copies of Hothead Paisan were seized. Toronto Women's Bookstore had three separate seizures of Bad Attitude, Hothead Paisan, and Quim. Weenie-Toons! Women Artists Mock Cock was held up at customs. Hothead 7 was seized despite having no sexual activity. 27 titles were seized from Le Dernier Mot, including "Woman Hating" and "Pornography: Men Possessing Women." Articles about the seizures have appeared in local newspapers. The seizures are possible because of Canada's Supreme Court Butler Decision, which held that pornography can be defined as things that do harm to women. The ruling has also been used against gay men's magazines. Appeals to the ruling were in process at the time of the article. The number of titles banned in Canada has grown from one title in 1986 to 5000 titles by 1992.

author: BookPeople
Brenda and Wanda Henson [Camp Sister Spirit]; Madelaine Zadik; Rose Maloof [Lunaria: A Feminist Bookstore]; Nikki [Women's Bookstop]; Marj Schneider [Womyn's Braille Press]; Nett Hart [Word Weavers].
Carol Seajay
notes: Photographs: Two women on the aisle at ABA; The Aunt Lute Books booth at ABA. ABA announced that they are suing five publishers for unfair trade practices that give chains and discounters unfair terms and other advantages that are not afford to independent booksellers. Seajay recounts how this announcement changed the entire energy of the ABA convention that year.

article_title: ABA Hires PR Firm to Promote Independent Bookstores
author: Carol Seajay
notes: The Feminist Bookstores' Network motion passed at the 1993 ABA Membership Meeting to "develop and implement, in 1993, a national promotional and advertising campaign in major media educating the American public about the importance and necessity of independent and specialty bookstores...".; The organization of national publicity campaigns to promote independent bookselling. A highlight of this campaign include the creation of a National Independent Booksellers Week, held for the first between the 5-12 of November.

author: Cathy Andrews
notes: Graphics: album covers featured in the advertisement

article_title: ABA '94: ABA Stands Up For Independents: Fights Unfair/Illegal Discounts in Court
author: Carol Seajay
notes: Follow up article on ABA anti-trust lawsuit against five publishers. ABA is charging the publishers with price discrimination, promotional allowance discrimination, and illegally favouring certain kinds of bookstores. The complained named Penguin USA, St. Martin's Press, Houghton Mifflin, Rutledge Hill Press, and Hugh Lauter Levin Associates. ABA does not seek monetary damages, but instead, urges the court to instruct publishers to cease engaging in such practices and to make the same advantages given to chain retailers proportionately available to all retailers.

article_title: Celebrate Your Independents: National Independent Bookstore Week Launched
author: Carol Seajay
notes: Wallis Group nationally promoted independent bookstores, invited ABA member bookstores to attend a local event. Funding of $200k-$250k to educate independent bookstores. Goal: to have five independent bookseller weeks in San Francisco a year. "If [FBN] can afford to send 500 free copies of its first catalog to all of its members, then it seems likely that ABA could afford to send packets to all of its members as well." Graphics: drawing of a singular eye looking at an open book held by a singular hand.

author: Carol Seajay
notes: Little Sisters arguing against unequal censorship by Canada Customs between heterosexual and homosexual pornography. The Women's Legal Educational and Action Fund joined Little Sister in support with their claim that heterosexual pornography harms women. Canada Custom's response: they bar anything violent or obscene. Canada Custom's hypocrisy: they approved Madonna's Sex which included visually violent and obscene heterosexual pornographic imagery. Highlights discrepancies such as how quickly homosexual pornography is labeled "obscene" whereas equal or more extreme heterosexual pornography is approved. Graphics: A comic of a person in a field holding a pole, by Diare DiMassa

author: Carol Seajay
notes: Updates from The Women's Bookstop in Hamilton, Ontario; Textures in San Antonio; The Book Garden in Denver; Everywoman's in BC Columbia; Fundraising for Toronto's Women's Bookstore; Thunder Road, a new lesbian/feminist book club; In Other Words, in Portland; Rubyfruit Bookstore; My Sister's Words; Silver Moon in London; Sisterspirit in San Jose; Crazy Ladies Bookstore; Women and Children First in Chicago; The Feminist Bookshop in Sydney, AUS; Full Circle; A Room of One's Own; some were having issues with traffic and not making sales goals; someone destroyed books at Amazon in Minneapolis during Banned Books week. author: Carol Seajay
notes: John Miller Arrested for Fraud; Judith's Room closed January 31, 1995 due to increasing rental rates in NYC; Lesbian & Feminist journals were found vandalized at the University of New Mexico Albuquerque library (damage estimated $24,000); Announcement that LAMMY nominations must be sent in by Feb. 3--new eligibility for Canadian, Australian, and British works. Pink Pyramid Bookstore has evidence in an obscenity case thrown out by Court Judge William Mallory--a win for free speech and queer booksellers; Gaia's Guide publisher Sandy Horn passed away on October 22, 1994, the short feature speaks of her accomplishments and directs donations to Cancerlink

author: Carol Seajay
notes: Aboriginal groups are asking that "Mutant Message Down Under" as it is spreading racist misinformation, The New York Times ran an article on bookstore chains (specifically charging for book display). First graphic: 'sylvia' by Nicole Hollander- Black woman and white woman in conversation: Black woman says, "Affirmative Action is Dead," to which the white woman responds, "Actually, I'm glad white guys have been so angry. Now they'll have full employment..." [second panel] Black woman says, "Go to all the best schools, get all the government contracts. Their lives will be perfect, and their happiness..." white woman finishes sentence, "will trickle down all over the rest of us". More news is covered including National Independent Bookstores Week, Feminist Bookstore Week/North America, calls for store participating in 'take your daughters to work day', and the Women's Review in Arabic (info on how to purchase), discussions on net income vs net sales (Carol disagrees with Barbara Grier, amiably). Oops! section: correcting where a source of information came from after it was mistakenly misprinted in a previous issue.

author: Carol Seajay

article_title: Selling Their Souls: The High Cost of Posting B&N Web Site Banners
author: Carol Seajay
notes: Organizations have put B&N banners on their website (they get money for doing so). Various responses from these organizations to outcry from feminist stores. Deconstructs some arguments for B&N (that rural, poor gay people need B&N and Amazon...small bookstores also use the mailing system) (that closeted people rely on anonymity of B&N rather than "racey" names...many bookstore names do not necessarily out people)

author: Carol Seajay
notes: ABA has new leadership/voting structure; Amazon.com finally stopped associating with homophobe Bob Enyart, going back on their defense of 'free speech' due to a letter-writing campaign. Carol Seajay questions why letter-writing campaign focused on homophobia rather than anti-semitism and misogyny as well; B&N news
